h i g h l i g h t s
Estimation of UCS of fiber reinforced cemented sand consisting nano calcium carbonate using UPV. The presence of fibers increases the UCS cemented sand. The addition of carpet waste fiber was found to increase the soil stiffness. Increasing the carpet waste fiber content above the 0.2% did not have much impact on the maximum strength, but significantly improved the residual strength. Keywords: Nano calcium carbonate Carpet waste fiber Clay Unconfined compressive strength Ultrasonic pulse velocity Unconsolidated undrained triaxial
a b s t r a c t
One of the geotechnical engineering strategies for dealing with weak soils in a construction site is to alter their mechanical properties with the assistance of soil improvement techniques. The present study examined the effect of the addition of nano calcium carbonate (0, 0.4, 0.8 and 1.2% by weight of the soil) as a stabilizing nanoparticle and carpet waste fibers (0, 0.2, 0.4, and 0.6% by weight of the soil) as a reinforcement agent on the soil behavior. A total of 52 unconfined compressive strength tests, 52 ultrasonic pulse velocity tests, 12 unconsolidated undrained (UU) triaxial tests, and 8 Atterberg limit tests were performed to investigate the effect of fiber and nanoparticle contents and treatment time on the geotechnical properties of the clayey soil. The results showed that the addition of nanoparticles to the clayey soil reduces its liquid limit and increases its plastic limit. The best improvement in the soil strength, which was about 100%, was observed in the 42 days old sample with 1.2% nano calcium carbonate content. The combined use of fibers and nanoparticles also led to significant strength improvement. The addition of carpet waste fiber was found to increase the soil stiffness. Increasing the carpet waste fiber content above the 0.2% did not have much impact on the maximum strength, but significantly improved the residual strength. The addition of carpet waste fibers up to 0.2% increased the velocity of ultrasonic waves, but further increase in the fiber content resulted in reduced velocity. The paper provides a number of equations that express the relationship between the unconfined compressive strength and the ultrasonic pulse velocity for the clayey soils with different additive contents. The provided equations can be used to estimate the success of stabilization and strength improvement efforts based on the results of non-destructive ultrasonic pulse velocity test. The results of unconsolidated undrained triaxial tests showed that the used fibers alter the sample behavior in high strains. Also, the use of nano calcium carbonate and carpet waste fibers together almost doubled the undrained cohesion.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Natural soils typically lack the mechanical and geotechnical properties that are deemed ideal for the construction projects,
and therefore require some manner of treatment to reach geotechnically favorable conditions. One strategy to achieve this goal is to alter the mechanical properties of the soil through the methods known as soil improvement techniques [1–11]. Most notable methods of eliminating the undesirable soil behaviors and improving the soil properties include reinforcement, stabilization with additives, compaction, drainage, and lowering of groundwater
level [12–23]. Soil stabilization agents include a wide array of materials such as lime, Portland cement, industrial by-products (e.g., fly ash, slag, etc.), polymers, fibers, chemical reagents, waste/recycled materials (e.g., shredded tire, crushed glass, etc.), asphalt emulsion, tar, bitumen and so on. Among many stabilization materials, soil stabilization with lime or cement is the most widely used technique [24–35].
Bell [24] explored the effect of lime treatment on geotechnical properties of clayey soil. He reported that Montmorillonitic clay experience the highest reduction in plastic limits whilst kaolinitic clays experience it to a lesser extent. Moreover quartz, lime does not have significant impact on the plastic limits. Sabat [25] explored the impacts of lime sludge and bagasse ash on mechanical and geotechnical characteristics of an expansive soil. He found that the best treatment impacts were obtained when the optimum percentage of lime sludge was 16% and bagasse ash was 8%. Manikandan and Moganraj [32] reported that the combined impact of lime and bagasse ash were more efficient than the impact of bagasse ash alone in controlling the consolidation characteristics of expansive soil. Rao et al., [33] investigated the impacts of gypsum, lime and rice husk ash, lime and on mechanical behavior clayey soil. They concluded that that unconfined compressive strength increased by 548% at 28 days of curing and CBR increased by 1350% at 14 days curing at RHA- 20%, lime 5% and gypsum 3%. Sabat [37] explored the impact of lime sludge and rice husk ash on shear strength properties, CBR, durability and compaction of clayey soil. He reported that the optimum proportion soil: lime sludge: rice husk ash was found to be 75:15:10. Amu et al. [38] used cement and fly ash for treatment of soil. The obtained results showed that, treatment impact of 3% fly ash and 9% cement was better than the stabilizing impact 12% cement. Meng et al. [39] investigated the effects of nano-CaCO3 on the properties of cemented soils in the marine environment. Irrespective of the curing condition (i.e., either standard or marine environment), the addition of nano-CaCO3 improved the compressive strength, enhanced corrosion resistance, and promoted generation of hydration products.
With the advancement of technology, engineers are now able to utilize nanoscale stabilizers as additives to improve the soil properties [40–47]. The interesting features of these materials stem from the great number of atoms and molecules at their free surface, and the resulting effects on their surface properties from physical, chemical and reactivity perspectives. Thanks to the high surface area and surface charge of nanoparticles, even small amounts of these additives can make noticeable improvements in soil behavior. Nanotechnology has contributed to geotechnical engineering in two ways. Firstly, it has facilitated the study of soil structure and nature of its behavior in nanometer scale, and secondly, the analyses of soil behavior in atomic and molecular scales have advanced the use of nanoparticles as soil additives [39,40].
Soil reinforcement by the use of fibers is another viable strategy for improving the soil mechanical properties. As a result, the use of discrete randomly distributed fibers of different materials for soil improvement has become a subject of great interest to engineers [49–57]. The primary merits of using discrete randomly distributed fibers are the preservation of soil consistency and the lack of potential planes of weakness that may emerge parallel to the oriented reinforcement. Another source of growing interest in this reinforcement strategy is the possibility of using waste materials for this purpose. For example, the United States Environmental Protection Agency [58] has reported this the US alone produces about 200 million tons of waste per year, about 5% of which is fibrous waste including textiles and carpet. Every year, huge amounts of textile and carpet waste are simply thrown
away. About half of this waste is from carpets and mainly consists of plastic and polymer fibers, which take a long time to decompose. With the development of recycling technology, these wastes can now be transformed into usable materials; an approach that will result in not only reduced landfilling problems but also noticeable cost saving in the carpet industry. Soil reinforcement with the assistance of recycled natural and synthetic fibers in order to improve its mechanical properties has been extensively researched, and promising results in this regard have been reported [36].
In general, waste materials are better to be recycled rather than being released in nature. Every year, industries produce significant quantities of fibrous textile and carpet wastes, which can occupy a significant amount of landfill space. The use of these wastes as soil reinforcement can be a perfect way to reduce their environmental impacts [46]. Another potentially promising approach to further improvement in this field is the use of nanotechnology to enhance the results that can be achieved with recycled materials. However, because of complexities of geotechnical engineering and the macroscopic view of geotechnical engineers and researchers toward the soil, the application of nanotechnology in this area has remained under-researched.
In the present work, a series of unconfined compressive tests, unconsolidated undrained triaxial tests, and ultrasonic pulse velocity tests were performed on the soil samples stabilized with nanomaterials and reinforced with carpet waste fibers. The samples used for this purpose were prepared based on several fiber/soil composition ratios ranging from 0.2% to 0.6%, and several nanoparticle/soil composition ratios ranging from 0.4% to 1.2%.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
The clayey soil used for sample preparation was collected from Babol in northern Iran. After measuring the grain size and Atterberg limits and comparing the results with the Unified Soil Classification System, the collected soil was classified as CL. The grading curve and properties of this soil are shown in Fig. 1 and Table 1, respectively.
The properties of nano calcium carbonate used in the study are given in Table 2. Fig. 2a shows an electron microscope image of nano calcium carbonate.
The carpet waste fiber used in the study is made of wool, typically used in carpet weaving industry. The fibers had a diameter of
0.8 mm, a length of 10 mm (Fig. 2b). The water used in all tests was distilled water.

sections.heading: 2.2. Sample preparation
sections.text:
Sample preparation is one of the most critical steps of experimental research. In this study, samples were prepared through the following procedure. First, the soil was dried in the oven and then divided into 10 equal parts. Each part was extensively mixed with a predetermined amount of nano calcium carbonate. Then, all parts were transferred to a container and the resulting mixture was stirred with an electric stirrer for 3 h. Afterwards, the water needed to achieve optimummoisture content and fibers were added to the mixture and the mixing process continued until reaching a homogeneous mixture. The resulting mixture was divided into 6 parts, each of which was compacted statically in a cylindrical container with a height of 100 mm and diameter of 50 mm. All samples were compressed to a compaction ratio of 95%. The samples were cured in two plastic bags until the date of tests (at 7, 14, 28 and 42 days). To assess the validity of the obtained results, two samples prepared from each mixing design and tested. After each test, the average error was calculated. The test results were considered suitable for presenting if their average error was less than 5%.

sections.heading: 2.3. Testing program
sections.text:
The tests of plastic limit and liquid limit were performed according to ASTM D4318 standard. The unconfined compressive strength test was performed according to ASTM D2166 at a strain rate of 1% per minute. The unconsolidated undrained triaxial strength test was performed under the confining pressures of 400, 600 and 800 kPa according to ASTM D2850 standard.
The effect of the percentage of nano calcium carbonate and carpet waste fiber and curing time on ultrasonic pulse velocity was also investigated. This investigation was carried out to establish the relationship between the unconfined compressive strength of samples and the wave velocity measurements. In the ultrasonic pulse velocity test, pulse frequency was 54 Hz and pulse transmission time was measured at 0.1 microsecond precision. Having the length of the wave transmission (sample length) and the measured transmission times, the velocity of the ultrasonic pulse in the sample was calculated using the following equation.

sections.heading: 3.1. Atterberg limits test
sections.text:
Fig. 4 shows the effect of the weight ratio of nano calcium carbonate on the plastic properties of the treated clayey soil. As the figure shows, the addition of nano calcium carbonate has reduced the liquid limit and increased the plastic limit of the clay. Since the plasticity index of the soil is the difference between its plastic limit and its liquid limit, the said changes result in a lower plasticity index. It should be noted that since nano calcium carbonate does not exhibit a plastic property, using it as an additive reduces the plastic property of the soil. Furthermore, with the addition of calcium carbonate to the soil, its calcium ions start to replace sodium and hydrogen ions and this process continues until the soil is saturated with calcium. With the replacement of sodium with calcium, the thickness of diffused double layer decreases. Hence, the
rbonate, b) carpet waste fiber.
plastic limit can be expected to decrease as well. The greater is the amount of nano calcium carbonate added, the greater will be the reduction of the thickness of the diffused double layer and consequently the greater will be the decrease in the plastic limit and the plasticity index. To explain this relation, it can also be argued that the added nano calcium carbonate causes the clay particles to bind together, and this results in further filling of voids and reduction of plastic limit. Taha and Ying [3] reported that addition of carbon nanotube to kaolinite soil increased plasticity index by 22%. Majeed and Taha [4] explored the impact of nanoclay (0.1%, 0.2% and 0.3%) on geotechnical properties of organic soil with low plasticity. They founded that adding nanoclay decreased Atterberg limits and plasticity index. Bahmani et al. [9] investigated the impact of nanosilica (0%, 0.2%, 0.4%, 0.8% and 1%) on Atterberg limits of cement stabilized clayey soil. Their results showed that addition of nanosilica leads to the reduction of plasticity index. Taha [10] explored impact of nanosoil (that obtained from ball mill) on geotechnical characteristics of original soil. They also reported that adding nanoclay decreased plasticity index. It should be noted that although increasing the plastic limit could be a desirable strategy for improving the geotechnical performance of the soil, the widespread use of nanoparticles needs to be cost-effective, and therefore requires further economic feasibility analysis.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Stress-strain curve
sections.text:
Fig. 5a shows the stress-strain curve obtained for the samples without nano calcium carbonate and with various carpet waste fiber contents. As can be seen, the greater is the fiber content, the higher is the maximum strength. However, in the sample with fiber contents of above 0.2%, the increase in the maximum strength is not noticeable. It can also be seen that the post-failure behavior of these samples highly depends on the amount of fiber added. In other words, the fibers play a more evident role at higher strains. This is because for the force mobilization to occur in the fiber, tensile strains should emerge near the fiber and a relative displacement should occur between the fiber and the soil particles. As a result, the fibers contribute better to the soil behavior when strain is higher. At high strains, the fibers bridge the two sides of the crack, allowing the stress to be transferred across it. In the absence of fiber, however, the formation of a crack will sever the bonds between the two sides, which will result in further strength reduction. The greater is the fiber content of the soil, the higher will be the number of fibers bridging the cracks, the better will be the stress transfer across the crack, and thus the more flexible will be the soil-fiber structure. Fig. 5a also revealed that, this type of
increasing stress–strain response has been similarly observed in the results of triaxial compression tests on cemented specimens with increasing confining stress [18,19]. This is because the addition of fiber prevents lateral deformation in the same way as the confining pressure. Therefore, the addition of fibers is a viable way to reduce fragile behavior of near-surface soils, where the confining pressure is low. Another important parameter for evaluating the soil behavior is the strain corresponding to the failure point. As can be seen, as fiber content increases, the equivalent confining pressure increases the failure strain.
Fig. 5b shows the stress-strain curve of the 7 days old samples stabilized with different nano calcium carbonate contents. As can be seen, adding this nanomaterial leads to the formation of an adhesive gel that binds the soil particles together, thus resulting in increased strength. The increased strength can also be explained by the formation of an integrated matrix due to the gel production. It can also be seen that the curves belonging to the samples with higher nano calcium carbonate contents have a more pronounced maximum strength. As stated above, the addition of nanoparticles increases the strength. On the other hand, there is a noticeable strength reduction at higher strains due to the reduced strength of integrated matrix and the degradation of adhesive gel structure.
As a result, the samples with higher nano calcium carbonate contents can be expected to have a more evident maximum strength.
Fig. 6 shows the stress–strain curve of 7 and 42 days old samples with 0.6% fiber content and different nano calcium carbonate contents. As shown in this figure, the samples with higher nanomaterial and carpet waste fiber contents have a higher strength. Also, the reinforced stabilized samples exhibit a post-failure strength degradation. A comparison between less and more aged samples reveals that the reinforced stabilized samples exhibit a more distinct behavior as they get older. In other words, as time passes, the cement bonds become stronger; thus after debonding at high strains, the reduction from maximum strength to residual strength is more noticeable. Another interesting result is the difference between the residual strengths of stabilized and nonstabilized samples, which, as shown in Fig. 6, is much greater in 42 days old samples than in their 7 days old counterparts. This is because of the strengthening of cement bonds with the passage of time. The amount of force mobilization in the fiber depends on the strength of the surrounding soil matrix. It is also notable that during the disintegration of the cement bonds created due to the addition of nano calcium carbonate, the sudden failure may induce a stress so large that cause the soil particles to debond
ent nano calcium carbonate contents a) 7 days old, b) 42 days old.
as well. This leads to a residual state where the fibers are surrounded by strong soil, thus resulting in reduced force mobilization in the fibers.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Unconfined compression strength
sections.text:
Fig. 7 shows the role of different factors on the maximum strength measured in the unconfined compression test. In Fig. 7, it can clearly be seen the increase in strength with the increase in nano calcium carbonate content for different curing times. The highest strength was measured in the sample with 1.2% nano calcium carbonate content. To explain this result, it should be stated that the chemical reactions between stabilizers and soil particles increase the soil strength. These chemical reactions lead to the formation of cementitious materials that bind the particles together, thus increasing the strength of the sample. In fact, the chemical reactions between the stabilizer and soil particles facilitate the filling of inter-particle void spaces and thereby increase the bonding between the particles. Calcium carbonate crystals play an essential role in the strengthening of the inter-particle bonds and the consequent soil stabilization. These chemical reactions are in fact timedependent, meaning that their results depend on the curing time. Luo et al. [12] explored effect of nano- Al2O3 on unconfined compressive strength of Sewage Sludge Ash-cement stabilized soil. It
was reported that the unconfined compressive strength stabilized soil with 1% nano alumina oxide is 4.2 higher than that of unstabilized soil after 7 days curing. Meng et al. [39] conducted unconfined compressive strength tests to explore the effect of nano calcium carbonate and curing condition (marine environment condition) on mechanical characteristics of clay stabilized with cement. They reported that the inclusion of nano calcium carbonate increased the unconfined compressive strength and corrosion resistance of cement treated clayey soil. Baziar et al. [13] studied the effect of nano clay on improving the geotechnical properties of clayey sand. They reported that the nano clay improve the drained and undrained triaxial strength and self healing property.
Fig. 7 also shows that the addition of carpet waste fibers increases the maximum strength. Since soil and fibers are closely bonded together, soil stresses are transferred to the fiber, and this leads to the creation of a force within the fiber. This force increases the strength in two ways. Firstly, it directly prevents the particles from sliding. Secondly, the vertical component of this force, which acts along the sliding surface, increases the vertical stress in this surface, thus resulting in increased shear strength as well. Since the transfer of force between the soil and the fiber is through their contact surface, with the increase in the fiber content and the consequent increase in the fiber-soil interface area, one can expect an
at a) 7 days, b) 14 days, c) 28 days, c) 42 days.
increase in the strength mobilization in the fiber and therefore an increase in the maximum strength of the entire mixture. Kumar et al. [17] mixed polyester fibers with highly compressible clayey soil and conducted several unconfined compressive strength tests. They reported that as the percentage polyester fiber content increases, the unconfined compressive strength value will increase. Park et al. investigated the effect polyvinyl alcohol fiber on the macanical beihvore of san with 4% cement. They reported that the inclusion of 1% fiber to cement treated sand resulted in a two times increase in the unconfined compressive strength when compared to unreinforced sample [18,19].
Regarding the combined effect of nano calcium carbonate and carpet waste fibers, it should be stated that application of a force to the reinforced soil results in the appearance of two mechanisms of failure and separation in the fiber. When the bonds between fiber and soil particles are strong enough to prevent sliding between them, a considerable force will be generated in the fibers. The strength of the said bond can be increased by increasing the confining pressure or adding cementitious material to the soil. The addition of nano calcium carbonate facilitates the formation of cement bonds between soil particles and fibers. Also, the micro-filling property of this nanomaterial increases the area of contact surface between soil and fibers. These two factors increase the resistance of the fibers to sliding, which leads to the creation of greater forces and ultimately increased strength. Changizi and Haddad [20] studided the effect of nano clay and glass fiber on the mechanical behavior of clay soil. They founded that the additional of nano clay resulted in an increase in the bonding strength between fiber and clay. With the prolongation of curing time and consequently further strengthening of cement bonds and production of reaction products, the bond strength increases, and this results in mobilization of a greater force under a constant deformation as the sample ages. Changizi and Haddad [40] investigated the impact of nano silica and polyester fiber on the behavior of a clay soil with a low liquid limit. The obtained results revealed that the inclusion of nano silica resulted in an increase in the bonding strength between fiber and clay.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Deformability coefficient
sections.text:
Fig. 8 shows the deformability coefficient equivalent to 50% maximum strength for the 42 days old non-reinforced samples and the 42 days old samples reinforced with 0.2% carpet waste and various nano calcium carbonate contents. This figure indicates
that the deformability coefficient of reinforced and non-reinforced samples increases with the increase in nano calcium carbonate content. In other words, as the bonding between soil particles increases, soil stiffness increases and its susceptibility to deformation decreases. Correira et al. [59] explored the impact of polypropylene fiber and binder on the mechanical properties of soft soil. They found that the increment of binder quantity improves the tensile strength, the compressive strength and the deformability coefficient of the soil. Regarding the impact of calcium carbonate on the stiffness of the reinforced sample, it can be stated that the cement bonds decrease the potential of fibers sliding over the soil matrix, and consequently increase the force mobilization in the fiber, which leads to an increased sample stiffness. As shown in Fig. 4, the increase in the fiber content also increases the sample stiffness. As indicated in pervious section, the addition of waste fibers creates an equivalent confining pressure, which results in increased resistance to deformation. Hence, the addition of fibers can be expected to increase the stiffness corresponding to 50% maximum strength. Ple and Le [60] conducted tension and compression tests on clayey soil reinforced with polypropylene fiber. Their results revealed a significant increase in deformability coefficient in the compression tests.

sections.heading: 3.3. Ultrasonic pulse velocity
sections.text:
Fig. 9 shows the ultrasound wave velocity of in the 7 and 42 days old samples with different nano calcium carbonate and carpet waste fiber contents. This figure indicates that as the nano calcium carbonate content increases, the ultrasonic wave velocity increases. This is because the addition of nanoparticles improves the microstructure in parallel to the sample length and increases the consistency and density of soil, which result in the creation of a better path for the passage of waves, and therefore increased wave velocity. Similar results were reported by Cristelo et al. [48] for Portland cement-sandy clay mixture. In other words, the addition of nano calcium carbonate can reduce the micro cracks and grooves in the soil matrix. Furthermore, the addition of cementitious material causes the particles to bind together, which transforms the soil matrix into an integrated structure. Therefore, the addition of nanoparticles can be expected to reduce the intraparticle pore space. Despite the increase in the inter-particle pore space, the ultrasonic pulses can pass through the pathway created by the integration of clay particles, which allows higher wave
old unreinforced and reinforced samples (0.2% fiber) with various nano calcium
velocities to be observed. Regarding the role of nano calcium carbonate on the ultrasonic wave velocity in the sample, it can be stated that the contact surface between fibers and soil particles is one of the weakest sections of the sample, but the micro-filling property of nanoparticles leads to improved property in the section. Also, the addition of nanomaterials leads to the replacement of water and therefore placement of a material with more desirable properties along the path of waves, which results in an increased wave passage velocity.
The results of Fig. 9 in regard to the effect of carpet waste fiber on the ultrasonic wave velocity indicates that the addition of fibers up to a weight ratio of 0.2% increases the velocity of ultrasonic waves, but using higher amounts result in relatively lower velocities. To explain this observation, it can be argued that since the volume of added fiber is higher than that of the soil with the same weight, the addition of fiber can be expected to significantly facilitate the filling of voids and consequently decrease the sample porosity, thereby resulting in increased ultrasonic wave velocity. On the other hand, since the carpet waste fiber is softer than the soil matrix, the addition of fibers can also slow down the passage of waves. Moreover, the sample preparation process, which includes applying pressure from the top, leads to relatively horizontal orientation of fibers, which puts them sideways in the path of the incoming waves. Such possibility was reported by Fatahi et al. [49], when analyzing the decrease of shear wave velocity in cemented clay samples with increasing percentage of fiber.
As a result, the waves are likely to diverge instead of traversing directly along the sample, and therefore require more time to pass the sample. Also, note that it would be very difficult to make sure that fibers are homogeneously distributed on a micro scale. During the sample preparation, mixing process is continued until reaching a visually confirmable homogeneous distribution. But the research in this regard has shown that, on the micro scale, distribution of mixed fiber will be inevitably heterogeneous. As a result, since the waves can get trapped in the heterogeneities, the sample has a multi-dimensional structure, which raises the possibility of wave interference. Hence, this can also reduce the velocity of waves passing through the sample. Overall, in the samples with low fiber contents, the factors that decrease the wave velocity have a more dominant effect, but in the samples with high fiber contents, the factors that increase the wave velocity are more dominant. For the samples of this study, the carpet waste fiber content that resulted in highest ultrasonic wave velocity was 0.2%. A Similar
result was founded by Kutanaei and Choobbasti [22] for cementnanosilica-sand mixture reinforced with PVA fiber. They reported that, addition of 0.3% PVA fiber increases the ultrasonic pulse velocity in almost all of the samples for all of the curing times, but adding more fiber (0.6 and 1%) decreases the ultrasonic velocity.
The ultrasonic pulse test can be used as a non-destructive procedure for controlling the quality and success of stabilization process. In line with this goal, we attempted to establish a relationship between the unconfined compressive strength and the ultrasonic wave velocity. Comparison of the results obtained from the ultrasonic pulse and uniaxial strength tests showed that the relationship between the results of these two tests varies with the amount of carpet waste fiber added to the sample. Hence, we present multiple equations that express this relationship for the samples with different fiber contents. Past studies in this area have shown that the relationship between unconfined compressive strength and ultrasonic pulse velocity is exponential. In Fig. 10, the unconfined compressive strength are plotted against the corresponding ultrasonic pulse velocity measurements made in the
samples with different carpet waste fiber contents, different nano calcium carbonate contents and curing times. As these figures show, the proposed equations have a high correlation coefficient, which is indicative of their high precision in estimating the unconfined compressive strength based on the velocity of the ultrasonic wave.

sections.heading: 3.4. Triaxial test
sections.text:
Fig. 11 shows the deviatoric stress-axial strain curves obtained for the control samples, the samples containing 0.4% carpet waste fiber, the samples containing 1.2% nano calcium carbonate, and the samples containing 0.4% carpet waste fiber and 1.2% nano calcium carbonate, all samples have been tested at the 28 days. As can be seen, the addition of carpet waste fibers and nano calcium carbonate has generally increased the soil stiffness. Another notable result is the slight difference between the curves of reinforced and nonreinforced samples in low strains and their growing difference as the axial strain increases. Li and Zornberg [50] reported such similar behavior at smaller strain levels, for reinforced sand and clay. To explain this growing difference, it can be argued that in low strains, the displacement between the soil particles and the carpet waste fibers is insignificant, and therefore so is the force mobilization in the fibers. Hence, fibers can be expected to play no role in the strength of the samples. But as the axial strain increases, a sufficiently large relative displacement at the contact surface between the fibers and soil particles start to induce tension in fibers, thereby improving the behavior of the samples in terms of strength and stiffness. As a result, in the situations where large strains can be expected (e.g. landslides), the addition of fibers will significantly improve the soil performance. In contrast, due to the nature of cement bonds to be formed following the addition of nano calcium carbonate, the use of this nanomaterial results in an immediate increase in strength and stiffness, which allow the soil to experience significant force mobilization even at low strains. Therefore, in the situations where strains are likely to remain low (e.g. machines foundations), soil behavior can be improved by the addition of nano calcium carbonate.
The failure envelopes of the tested samples are plotted in Fig. 12. As can be seen, following the addition of carpet waste fibers or nano-calcium carbonate, the failure envelope moves toward the right and top of the plot, which indicates an improvement in the shear behavior. But the best improvement in the shear strength occurs when carpet waste fibers and nano calcium carbonate are added simultaneously. Ahmad et al. [61] investigated the effect
of oil-palmempty-fruit-bunch fiber on the triaxial compression behavior of reinforced silty sand. They found that the shear strength parameters of the silty snad-fiber mixture can be improved significantly. Table 3 presents the shear strength parameters of the samples with different mix designs and the undrained cohesion obtained from the unconfined compressive test, which equals the half of unconfined compressive strength. It can be seen that the addition of carpet waste fibers and nano calcium carbonate has not significantly increased the undrained cohesion. For example, the addition of fibers, nano calcium carbonate and a combination of the two to the soil has increased the undrained cohesion by 1.46, 1.99 and 1.94 times respectively. Similar result was reported by Muntohar [62] for lime and rice husk ash-treated fine-grained soils that yields a substantial increase in cohesion and minor improvement in the internal friction angle. Moreover increasing the undried cohesion with the inclusion of polypropylene fibers was also reported by Cai et al. [63] for lime treated clay. Also, the undrained cohesion obtained from the undrained triaxial test is greater than the one from the unconfined compressive test. It should be noted that since the samples are not fully saturated, the application of confining pressure improves the compaction and increases the contact surface of the particles. Hence, the adhesion obtained from the triaxial test can be expected to be slightly higher than that of the unconfined compressive test. In this study, the maximum difference between the cohesion values obtained from these two tests was about 8%.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this study, a series of tests were carried out to evaluate the effects of the addition of nano calcium carbonate, carpet waste fibers, and treatment time on the strength and geotechnical properties of clay. Other limitations linked to soil, nanoparticle and fiber were investigated. Further research is still necessary to check if such a result might be spread to other fibers (e.g., coir, nylon,
sisal, glass, polyester, palmand, jute and polypropylene), nanoparticles (nano silica, nanoclay, nano titanium, carbon nanotube, nano alumina, nano zeolite, nano copper), soils (e.g., sand, gravel, silt and loess. The results of this study are summarized as follows:
1. Adding nanoparticles to the clayey soil decreases its liquid limit and increases its plastic limit, which results in a decrease in the plasticity index. This effect can be effectively used for soil improvement in the cases where the plasticity index of the soil needs to be decreased. 2. According to the results of unconfined compressive tests, the best improvement in the sample strength, which was about 100%, was achieved by adding 1.2% nano calcium carbonate and after 42 days of treatment. The combined use of fibers and nanoparticles also resulted in significant improvement in the sample strength. The addition of carpet waste fibers increased the sample stiffness. Increasing the carpet waste fiber content above the weight ratio of 0.2% did not have much impact on the maximum strength, but significantly improved the residual strength. With 1.2% nano calcium carbonate, an increase of 50% in unconfined compressive strength is observed for the mixtures with 0.6% carpet waste fiber. 3. The highest ultrasonic wave velocity was measured in the aged sample with 1.2% nano calcium carbonate content. Specimens prepared with 1.2% nano calcium carbonate had an ultrasonic wave velocity increase of 30–40% compared to unstabilized specimens. The addition of carpet waste fibers up to 0.2% increased the velocity of ultrasonic waves (about 5–10%), but further increase in the fiber content resulted in reduced velocity. Since the relationship between the unconfined compressive strength and ultrasonic pulse velocity varied with the level of fiber content, multiple equations for the relationship between these two parameters for different fiber contents have been presented. The provided equations can be used to estimate the success of stabilization process and strength improvement based on the results of non-destructive ultrasonic pulse velocity test. 4. The results of unconsolidated undrained triaxial tests conducted on the clayey soil samples indicate that the used fibers affect the sample behavior in high strains. Also, the addition of nano calcium carbonate and fibers together almost doubled the undrained cohesion. By adding 0.4% carpet waste fiber 1.2% nano calcium carbonate, the increase ratio of cohesion for treated specimens are 1.95.

metadata.abstractText: One of the geotechnical engineering strategies for dealing with weak soils in a construction site is to alter their mechanical properties with the assistance of soil improvement techniques. The present study examined the effect of the addition of nano calcium carbonate (0, 0.4, 0.8 and 1.2% by weight of the soil) as a stabilizing nanoparticle and carpet waste fibers (0, 0.2, 0.4, and 0.6% by weight of the soil) as a reinforcement agent on the soil behavior. A total of 52 unconfined compressive strength tests, 52 ultrasonic pulse velocity tests, 12 unconsolidated undrained (UU) triaxial tests, and 8 Atterberg limit tests were performed to investigate the effect of fiber and nanoparticle contents and treatment time on the geotechnical properties of the clayey soil. The results showed that the addition of nanoparticles to the clayey soil reduces its liquid limit and increases its plastic limit. The best improvement in the soil strength, which was about 100%, was observed in the 42 days old sample with 1.2% nano calcium carbonate content. The combined use of fibers and nanoparticles also led to significant strength improvement. The addition of carpet waste fiber was found to increase the soil stiffness. Increasing the carpet waste fiber content above the 0.2% did not have much impact on the maximum strength, but significantly improved the residual strength. The addition of carpet waste fibers up to 0.2% increased the velocity of ultrasonic waves, but further increase in the fiber content resulted in reduced velocity. The paper provides a number of equations that express the relationship between the unconfined compressive strength and the ultrasonic pulse velocity for the clayey soils with different additive contents. The provided equations can be used to estimate the success of stabilization and strength improvement efforts based on the results of non-destructive ultrasonic pulse velocity test. The results of unconsolidated undrained triaxial tests showed that the used fibers alter the sample behavior in high strains. Also, the use of nano calcium carbonate and carpet waste fibers together almost doubled the undrained cohesion. 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
